verses.text: Josiah was eight years old when he became king, and he reigned thirty-one years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Jedidah, the daughter of Adaiah of Bozkath.
verses.comment: Names and ages are consistent with the Hebrew text. Cross-reference to 2 Chronicles 34:1.

verses.text: He did what was right in the sight of the LORD and walked in all the ways of David his father, and did not turn aside to the right or to the left.
verses.comment: Phrase 'David his father' is maintained as meaning ancestor, as consistent with the Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: In the eighteenth year of King Josiah, the king sent Shaphan, the son of Azaliah, son of Meshullam, the scribe, to the house of the LORD, saying,
verses.comment: Terms like 'scribe' can mean 'secretary' or 'court official.' The Hebrew 'bayit YHWH' is rendered 'house of the LORD.'

verses.text: Go up to Hilkiah the high priest, so that he may count the money that has been brought into the house of the LORD, which the doorkeepers have collected from the people.
verses.comment: The phrase 'doorkeepers' is a direct translation of the Hebrew 'shomer hasaf,' meaning those responsible for collection.

verses.text: And let them deliver it into the hand of the workmen who have the oversight of the house of the LORD; and let them give it to those doing the work, who repair the damage of the house—
verses.comment: Terms like 'overseers' and 'workmen' are rendered literally for clarity.

verses.text: to the carpenters, the builders, and the masons. Also to buy timber and hewn stone to repair the house.
verses.comment: Trades are named as given in the text; 'hewn stone' is a literal rendering from the Hebrew.

verses.text: But let no accounting be required of them for the money given into their hand, because they deal faithfully.
verses.comment: The Hebrew term indicates implicit trust in the workers' honesty.

verses.text: And Hilkiah the high priest said to Shaphan the scribe, "I have found the Book of the Law in the house of the LORD." And Hilkiah gave the book to Shaphan, and he read it.
verses.comment: The 'Book of the Law' is traditionally understood as part or all of Deuteronomy; 'book' is from the Hebrew 'sefer.'

verses.text: And Shaphan the scribe came to the king, and brought the king word again, and said, "Your servants have poured out the money that was found in the house, and have delivered it into the hand of the workmen who have the oversight of the house of the LORD."
verses.comment: 'Brought the king word again' is rendered for modern clarity; Hebrew idiom maintained.

verses.text: And Shaphan the scribe told the king, "Hilkiah the priest has given me a book." And Shaphan read it before the king.
verses.comment: The text presents the reading of the law before the king as significant. 'A book' keeps the ambiguity of the original.

verses.text: When the king heard the words of the Book of the Law, he tore his clothes.
verses.comment: Tearing clothes is a Hebrew sign of grief or repentance.

verses.text: Then the king commanded Hilkiah the priest, Ahikam the son of Shaphan, Achbor the son of Micaiah, Shaphan the scribe, and Asaiah the king's servant, saying,
verses.comment: Names and titles rendered as in the original; 'servant' is 'eved,' a court official.

verses.text: "Go, inquire of the LORD for me, for the people, and for all Judah, about the words of this book that has been found. For great is the wrath of the LORD that is kindled against us, because our fathers have not listened to the words of this book, to do all that is written for us."
verses.comment: 'Wrath of the LORD' is retained as in the original for theological accuracy.

verses.text: So Hilkiah the priest, Ahikam, Achbor, Shaphan, and Asaiah went to Huldah the prophetess, the wife of Shallum son of Tikvah, son of Harhas, keeper of the wardrobe. She lived in Jerusalem in the Second Quarter, and they spoke with her.
verses.comment: 'Second Quarter' (Hebrew 'mishneh') probably refers to a district in Jerusalem. All names are rendered in a straightforward transliteration.

verses.text: And she said to them, "Thus says the LORD, the God of Israel: Tell the man who sent you to me:
verses.comment: 'Thus says the LORD' is the standard formula for prophetic oracles.

verses.text: "Thus says the LORD: Behold, I will bring disaster on this place and on its inhabitants, all the words of the book which the king of Judah has read.
verses.comment: 'Disaster' (Hebrew 'ra'ah') also means 'evil' or 'trouble,' here a judgment.

verses.text: Because they have forsaken me and have burned incense to other gods, so as to provoke me to anger with all the works of their hands. Therefore my wrath will be kindled against this place and it will not be quenched."
verses.comment: 'Burned incense' is a literal translation from 'qatar.' 'Works of their hands' refers to idolatry.

verses.text: But to the king of Judah who sent you to inquire of the LORD—this is what you shall say to him: Thus says the LORD, the God of Israel: About the words that you have heard—
verses.comment: The phrase 'inquire of the LORD' is consistent with the Hebrew 'darash eth-YHWH.'

verses.text: Because your heart was tender, and you humbled yourself before the LORD when you heard what I spoke against this place and its inhabitants—how they would become a desolation and a curse—and you tore your clothes and wept before me, I have also heard you, says the LORD.
verses.comment: 'Humbled yourself' is from Hebrew 'kana', meaning submission or repentance.

verses.text: Therefore, behold, I will gather you to your fathers, and you shall be gathered to your grave in peace, and your eyes shall not see all the disaster that I will bring on this place.'" So they took the message back to the king.
verses.comment: 'Gathered to your fathers' is a Hebrew idiom for dying and being buried with ancestors. 'In peace' is preserved as in the original.
